Vitamin A is a fat-soluble vitamin that is stored in the liver.
There are two types of vitamin A that are found in the diet.
-> Preformed vitamin A is found in animal products such as meat, fish, poultry, and dairy foods.
-> Precursors to vitamin A, also known as provitamin A, are found in plant-based foods such as fruits and vegetables. The most common type of provitamin A is beta-carotene.
Vitamin A is also available in dietary supplements. It most often comes in the form of retinyl acetate or retinyl palmitate (preformed vitamin A), beta-carotene (provitamin A) or a combination of preformed and provitamin A.

Thiamin(also spelled Thiamine) helps the body\'s cells change carbohydrates into energy. The main role of carbohydrates is to provide energy for the body, especially the brain and nervous system.\nThiamin also plays a role in muscle contraction and conduction of nerve signals.\nThiamin is essential for the metabolism of pyruvate, which is an important molecule in several chemical reactions in the body.
Helps your body break down and release energy from food.\nKeeps your nervous system healthy.

Riboflavin is a type of B vitamin. It is water-soluble, which means it is not stored in the body. Water-soluble vitamins dissolve in water. Leftover amounts of the vitamin leave the body through the fluid body waste. The body keeps a small reserve of these vitamins. They have to be taken on a regular basis to maintain the reserve.\nRiboflavin (vitamin B2) works with the other B vitamins. It is important for body growth. It helps in red blood cell production. It also aids in the release of energy from proteins.

Niacin is a type of B vitamin. It is water-soluble, which means it is not stored in the body. Water-soluble vitamins dissolve in water. Leftover amounts of the vitamin leave the body through the fluid body waste. The body keeps a small reserve of these vitamins. They have to be taken on a regular basis to maintain the reserve.\nNiacin helps the digestive system, skin, and nerves to function. It is also important for changing food to energy.
Helps your body release energy from food.\nKeeps your nervous system and skin healthy.

Vitamin B6 is a water-soluble vitamin. \nLack of vitamin B6 in the body is uncommon. It can occur in people with kidney failure, liver disease, or alcohol dependence.

Makes hemoglobin. Hemoglobin carries oxygen in the red blood cells to the tissues. A vitamin B6 deficiency can cause a form of anemia.
Breaks down proteins. The more protein you eat, the more vitamin B6 you need.
